title: How are stars always in the same place? - Quora

response.answer_text: They’re not. All of them are moving relative to us and relative to each other, and very fast. They appear not to be moving because they’re so far away. Similar to when you’re driving, and the lamp posts go by quickly but the distant mountains go by slowly. You’re actually passing them both at the same speed, but the distance and perspective make it appear that the mountains are slower. Now think about driving and looking at the moon. That will seem not to be moving at all, because it’nearly 250,000 miles away. And the sun, which is 93,000,000 miles away. When measuring the distance to a star, the usual measuring unit is the ‘light year’. One light year is 63,000 times farther than from Earth to the sun. That’s 5,878,000,000,000 miles. And the very nearest star is 4.22 light year from Earth. How fast are the stars moving? Our own sun (dragging all the planets with it) is moving at 450,000 miles per hour around the galaxy (which itself is also moving, even faster, in the direction of the Andromeda galaxy). A ‘fast’ moving star can go as fast as 2,000,000 miles per hour. We just can’t see that at this distance.

Stars of-course are moving, they only give the perception of standing still because of the great distance between the Earth and the star. Remember when you look at a star that is far away, you’re effectively looking back in time. Light has to travel a great distance to reach your eyes, because of this you perceived the star as being stationary.

The earths orbit around the sun makes them appear to orbit around the North Star but that happens over the 365 days of the solar year.
